item.title: Ticket #3259 (Should compress javascripts to save space) updated
item.dc:creator: andy
item.description: As long as the only changes from the original script are whitespace, I wouldn't worry about code maintenance issues here.

item.title: Ticket #3256 (Move TinyMCE to a plugin) updated
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
I wish TinyMCE were a plugin, just because it would be a lot easier to keep it up-to-date. Presumably as a plugin, like Akismet, it could be updated at more frequent intervals than stable WordPress is, allowing us to take advantage of the latest TinyMCE developments.

As it is now, you have to 1) wait for someone to port TinyMCE changes into WP trunk, then 2) wait for the next stable WP.

Any other places where some of the less common protocols are getting stripped out?

item.title: Ticket #3256 (Move TinyMCE to a plugin) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: And actually, that solution would be very much like a plugin that was activated by default... the deactivation is the act of deleting it.

item.title: Ticket #3256 (Move TinyMCE to a plugin) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
It's not going to be moved to a plugin, but if you want to make it easier to remove it, I'm reasonably sure that no one would object to that.

Right now, you can do rm -rf wp-includes/js/tinymce/ and that works reasonably well, but it still tries to load the JS. One solution might be to make a tinymce_exists() function that checks for the tinymce JS file using file_exists() that result should be cached in a global variable, so that it is only checked once per Post screen load.

Go ahead and open a new ticket if you want to do that. I'd definitely be in favor of that.

item.title: Ticket #3258 (Quotes in image titles mess up validation) created
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description: If you use double quotes in an image title, they are put verbatim into the HTML, which of course breaks the quoting.

item.title: Ticket #3253 (Give parnent of current page/category a CSS class) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
I agree, but we're already using current_page; I went for current_page_parent for the sake of parallelism. It'd be very confusing to people if one were one way and the other were the other.

How about we give the current page both current_page and current-page and give the parent just current-page-parent?

item.title: admin-functions.php.diff attached to Ticket #2726
item.dc:creator: CSiefkes
item.description: Patch that allows irc: links in the sidebar

item.title: Ticket #2726 (irc://irc.server.org cannot be written into a post / link) updated
item.dc:creator: CSiefkes
item.description:
Not being able to use irc: links within posts is only part of the problem. It is also impossible to add irc: links to the sidebar using the Site Admin interface (link manager) -- they will always be prefixed by ​http:// . For sidebar links, it is impossible to work around this problem, since there is no graphical editor you could turn off to avoid filtering.

I'll attach a patch to wp-admin/admin-functions.php that fixes this other half of the problem.

item.title: Ticket #3256 (Move TinyMCE to a plugin) updated
item.dc:creator: masquerade
item.description: ​http://comox.textdrive.com/pipermail/wp-hackers/2006-September/008463.html This thread tried, in a million ways, to convince anyone that the RTE should be a plugin activated by default. As you can see already, it failed.

NESSUS SECURITY SCAN REPORT

item.title: Ticket #3256 (Move TinyMCE to a plugin) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
I didn't say don't include it with WordPress or not have it enabled/activated in a fresh install (it's great for the less technically inclined), but I think it'd be best to have is a plugin rather than in the wp-includes folder. This makes it easier to get rid of and more importantly, easier to replace with something else.

I'll take the idea to wp-hackers though.

item.title: Ticket #3256 (Move TinyMCE to a plugin) created
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Make TinyMCE a plugin so that WordPress can run without it properly. It's a pain in the ass to have to upload all the files for it each time I setup WordPress somewhere.

I envision if you disable it, the option to enable it disappears and the write screen acts as if you have it off. If you enable the plugin, it acts exactly like it does now.

I'll make a patch tomorrow if I get a chance unless I hear any objections.

item.title: Ticket #3235 (New post marked as private gets published as public on submission) updated
item.dc:creator: erictrudeau
item.description:
This makes sense now that you explain it that way. I still almost see it as problem personally because what if I accidentally hit the publish button and something private went public.

I really like the idea of a separate section for the private posts... more like a personal journal.

Thanks guys and keep up the great work!

item.title: Ticket #3254 (Plugin sandboxing) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Fatal errors in plugins make your entire blog unusable. If someone is editing or activating a plugin through WordPress and this happens, they might not know what to do (FTP in and delete or rename the plugin file).

We should, upon plugin load (and maybe in-WP plugin editing), load the plugin into a sandbox environment, with actual plugin activation as a shutdown hook. If the plugin throws fatal errors, it won't get activated.

item.title: Ticket #3238 (Bug Fix in wpautop for Dangling Paragraph Tag in Wordpress Comments) updated
item.dc:creator: Ghidra99
item.description:
foolswisdom, I just took a look at the trunk code for ​formatting.php and it includes the bug as well.

It's at ​line 72: 

$pee = preg_replace('/\n?(.+?)(?:\n\s*\n|\z)/s', "<p>$1</p>\n", $pee); // make paragraphs, including one at the end

The updated code should read: 

$pee = preg_replace('/\n?(.+?)(?:\n\s*|\z)/s', "<p>$1</p>\n", $pee); // make paragraphs, including one at the end

Unfortunately, I'm not sure how to create patch files so this would be easily readable.

invalid:

Can we not file things that are not directly related to the code, especially issues that nobody in the community but Matt or someone else with server admin status, as a bug here? I'd say bring it up on one of the lists or e-mail Matt directly, but seeing as this has nothing to do with the WordPress code, it really doesn't belong here.

item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description: Severity changed

item.title: Ticket #3251 (wordpress.org/search each page displays same results and sometimes no ...) created
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
wordpress.org/search each page displays same results and sometimes no results are found

EXAMPLE:

​http://wordpress.org/search/css?documentation=1&p=2

results are identical to

​http://wordpress.org/search/css?documentation=1&p=200

Sometimes a search will report no results.

ADDITIONAL DETAILS

I played around with the code for a while and the code looks good. My guess is that it is a "proxy" issue or cache.

item.title: Ticket #3248 (Need way to replace WPDB error message) updated
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
You can achieve that by setting $wpdb to some value before including wp-db.php and setting it to your derived class afterwards.

wp-db.php only instantiates $wpdb if it's not already set.

Not the most elegant way, but it works.

item.title: wp_redirect.diff attached to Ticket #3250
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Patch for trunk

item.title: Ticket #3250 (Add filter (with cancel ability) to wp_redirect() function) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Patch adds a filter to the $location in wp_redirect. If $location is false after the filter, the function aborts, which means that a filter would be able to cancel a given redirect.

While writing a plugin today, I happened upon a circumstance where this would have been very useful.

item.title: Ticket #3249 (Nothing in wp-db.php is translatable) updated
item.dc:creator: Sewar
item.description:

We may need to change the way in which wpdb is instantiated to make this easier. As at present you can't include the real wpdb and extend it without $wpdb being created as normal.

item.title: Ticket #3248 (Need way to replace WPDB error message) created
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
We need some way to easily replace the error message(s) for unable to connect to the database in wp-db.php. A hook wouldn't work 'cause no plugins would run before then (since we don't know what's activated), so perhaps something in the same way that advanced-cache.php works would be in order.

Thoughts?

item.title: Ticket #3247 (Planet feed on Dashboard obscures titles and source sites) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Honestly, I'm not thrilled with the current "uniform boxes" look of that part of the dashboard... but were that to stay, I'd say that it'd be best to figure out (conservatively) how many characters can find on a line, and if it exceeds, chop the last 4 and add " ..."

We could have some more breathing room if the font size were smaller.

Finally, it'd at least look a little bit better if the height of the title/site were such that a certain number of lines would show, exactly (no mid-line chop). It looks to be a few pixels off from that, right now.
